text: first of all. It’s bad practice to do `onClick` in xml but w/e
If your `onClick` is set to your Button it will on listen if there was a click on the button
I don't have a specific onClick
If you want it to the whole screen add it to the LinearLayout
You do in your repo

```
    <Button
        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
        android:layout_margin="16dp"
        android:text="Eat cookie"
        android:onClick="eatCookie" />
```
You have 0 listeners in your code.

hey guys, quick question:
what do you think of signing different applications with the same certificate / store key?

my use case is building different applications with different package name/appId and different variables *but same code from the same project*.
so there's an inherent connection between this, I guess, "group" of apps. 
what do you think? is there a considerable drawback to sharing the same signing certificate on all of my apps?
Are they going on play store?
I have used same signing certificated for 10+ apps before no issue with it As long you following all piracy and other copyright rules..
but use same keystore for one account but not on multiple accounts (which is i guess you dont allow anyway)
well
in case your app gets super popular, and you might want to sell it to someone, I’d sign each with its own cert
so - different certificates

I’ve got a question regarding overdraw reduction…. My app is a single-activity app, where navigation is handled by swapping out fragments. In order to help with overdraw, in `onPostResume` for the root Activity, I’m calling `getWindow().setBackgroundDrawable(null)`. This is working to reduce overdraw, but now whenever I change fragments, there’s a bit of a GPU glitch where things look screwy  before the fragment transition is complete.  Does anybody have experience with this issue?
<@U16GF1B0F>: use that for your background instead of whatever layout you're using
that's the background of the window
if you set it to null (transparent) it's gonna glitch out like you've noticed
"use that for your background instead of whatever layout you're using”  not sure what you mean
<@U16GF1B0F>: instead of relying on your Activity/Fragment's layout to provide the background, set it on the window directly
that’s unfortunately not an option here.. the design dictates a textured background that scrolls along with the content inside of the scrollviews/recyclerviews…
it it were a solid color then I’d agree
<@U16GF1B0F>: well unless you're sure it's an issue I wouldn't worry about overdraw for now
otherwise just set the window background to something temporary during transitions

Hi guys. Quick question.
What library/approach/technique do you use for input validation
Good question, I’d be curious to know peoples’ answers too, going to be a lot of that in my next milestone

depends on what kind of input validation we’re talking about. We have an onboarding/registration feature where we wrote ourselves - it’s quite simple. Data goes in, you validate according to your rules, you show an error message or enable the continue button if it’s all ok
depending on the form/flow, you might want to validate an individual field, or the whole form

<@U053PPGDC>: do you mean attaching a textwatcher or something like that to individual input fields and checking the inputs yourself. I was actually thinking along the lines to specifying the kind of validation you want (say 5 <= length <=10, or some form of pattern, etc),and let the framework/library/whatever take care of validating them
yeah we wrote something in those lines
don’t know whether it exists tho
At the point of submission, I usually find myself doing a lot of checks. I do feel there must be better ways of getting things like that done
Some internal work yea?

attachments.fallback: [July 27th, 2016 6:15 PM] zmarkan: don’t know whether it exists tho
attachments.text: don’t know whether it exists tho

text: <@U1HM4MPLJ>: if you're into Rx, something like this might be helpful <https://www.vokal.io/labs/reactive-forms-with-rxandroid>

attachments.title: Reactive Forms with RxAndroid | Vokal
attachments.text: Reactive Programming has been getting a lot of attention in the Android community lately. While it has uses throughout the application stack, we're going to focus here on using it to validate forms (exciting!). This approach cuts down on ugly nested if statements and transforms all of the validation logic to just a few simple lines using the RxJava framework. More, it's robust and testable.

text: Hmmm. Yes, Rx is something I intend to take a deeper look into soon enough. At the moment, no
I'm leaning towards a conclusion that there really isn't a universal solution to input validation, on Android at least
I'll just go ahead with my current approach, knowing I'm not alone
Thank you :slightly_smiling_face:

Hey guys, I'm using a 3rd party ORM library. Is is possible to run a sql script on app start even if the library doesn't have the functionality to do so?
The db already exists in the app, now I want to, kind of like, override the sql execution by using a raw query.
<@U0SNJDQDC>: it is possible, i have done this in my project while I was using ormlite
Any tutorial/guides in doing so? I never used native SQLite helper though

Let's say I create a sql file in `assets/migrations/` called `2.sql` _(generic way in ActiveAndroid)_, now how do I run this sql file from Application class? I'm not using ActiveAndroid btw. But had experience using it before for migration stuff.

<@U0SNJDQDC>: you can implement it inside onCreate method of Class which extends OrmLiteSqliteOpenHelper, also I’m not sure if there is a way to run sql script file directly, I was implementing it with TableUtils Class in ormlite library.
